content.description: This is the obvious white dike that starts about 20 feet off the ground on the right side of the slab. X-rated. No gear until well above the crux and onto easy terrain. There is a flake that takes gear at around 100 feet. A fall from the crux could likely be fatal.Â
content.protection: X-rated. No gear friction climb. Not hard but very heady and a fall could be fatal.

content.description: The original slab route on this part of the wall. No gear until the angle eases off. Starts at a short left-facing flake on the far right of the practice slab. Work your way up the easiest line to a gear anchor at 125'. Another short pitch to the trees or easy terrain.

On the far left past the base of the Practice Slab, right of the old red trail, break out right and climb up easy friction slab through tree bands to reach an overlap. Climb the obvious right-leaning crack to easy slab above.
content.location: Left of the main practice slab.

content.description: Long 250-300ft low angle slab that goes right along the old Red hiking trail. No official route names as far as I know and mostly a solo climb, but there are some bolts placed in a few spots here. At least 1 double-bolt anchor roughly 80ft off the ground that could be used as TR anchor, and a series of bolts that traverse to the anchor from the side (I just solo'd it per local recommendation). All open slab from there to the top w/ minimal pro but it eases up into 3rd/4th class slab.**NOTE: The two bolt anchor on the left side should not be used until it can be replaced. The corrosion caused by a steel bolt and aluminum hanger have made it unsafe. The same is true of the bolts leading out the anchor from higher up on the left side.
